channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2025 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Author Correction: Selenium-alloyed tellurium oxide for amorphous p-channel transistors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09667-8

Author Correction: Selenium-alloyed tellurium oxide for amorphous p-channel transistors

A tweezer array with 6100 highly coherent atomic qubits

item.title: Industry-compatible silicon spin-qubit unit cells exceeding 99% fidelity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09531-9

Two-qubit operations exceeding 99% fidelity have been demonstrated by silicon devices made with standard semiconductor tooling in a 300-mm foundry environment.
item.dc:title: Industry-compatible silicon spin-qubit unit cells exceeding 99% fidelity

item.title: Isothermal solidification for high-entropy alloy synthesis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09530-w

Gallium is used as a sacrificial agent and mixing medium for the isothermal solidification synthesis of high-entropy alloy nanomaterials with diverse crystallinities and morphologies.
item.dc:title: Isothermal solidification for high-entropy alloy synthesis
item.dc:creator: Qiubo Zhang
Max C. Gallant

item.title: Electrostatic-repulsion-based transfer of van der Waals materials
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09510-0

An electrostatic-repulsion-enabled advanced transfer technique based on ammonia solution is introduced for separating van der Waals thin-film materials from their substrates, demonstrating suitability for its use in the complementary metal–oxide–semiconductor (CMOS) industry.
item.dc:title: Electrostatic-repulsion-based transfer of van der Waals materials
item.dc:creator: Xudong Zheng

item.title: Low-overhead transversal fault tolerance for universal quantum computation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09543-5

Logical operations can be performed fault-tolerantly with only a constant number of syndrome extraction rounds for a broad class of quantum error correction codes, including the surface code with magic state inputs and feedforward, to achieve ‘transversal algorithmic fault tolerance’.
item.dc:title: Low-overhead transversal fault tolerance for universal quantum computation
item.dc:creator: Hengyun Zhou
Chen Zhao
Madelyn Cain
Dolev Bluvstein
Nishad Maskara
Casey Duckering
Hong-Ye Hu
Sheng-Tao Wang
Aleksander Kubica
Mikhail D. Lukin

item.title: Electrostatic-based transfer keeps 2D materials ultra-clean
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02822-1

A technique that spontaneously detaches a 2D material from the substrate on which it was grown creates high-quality nanoscale electronic devices.
item.dc:title: Electrostatic-based transfer keeps 2D materials ultra-clean
item.dc:creator: Wanqing Meng
Lain-Jong Li
